docs.lead_paragraph: Some people think older houses have more charm. A study being published today suggests that they may also offer a healthful benefit: people in cities and suburbs who live in houses built before 1974 are almost 50 percent more likely to walk a lot for pleasure, it found. Of course, it's not the house itself that makes the difference, said the study's lead researcher, Dr. David Berrigan of the National Cancer Institute, as much as the neighborhood it's in. Dr. Berrigan said he concluded that development patterns in the 1950's and 60's were more conducive to an active lifestyle than development since then.

headline.main: Some Streets Are Made for Walking

docs.abstract: Study led by National Cancer Institute researcher Dr David Berrigan concludes that people living in cities and suburbs who live in houses built before 1974 are almost 50 percent more likely to walk a lot for pleasure; says housing development patterns of 1950's and 1960's were more conducive to active lifestyle; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There's an old saying among doctors and nurses who become seriously ill: don't get your medical care at the hospital where you work. It brings too much embarrassment and not enough privacy. But my colleague Catherine received most of her treatment at our hospital after she developed cancer in 1996.

headline.main: In the Death Of a Doctor, A Lesson

docs.abstract: Dr Barron Lerner Cases column recalls what he, other doctors and interns learned from colleague as she was being treated for cancer at hospital where they worked and where she eventually died (M)
docs.snippet: There's an old saying among doctors and nurses who become seriously ill: don't get your medical care at the hospital where you work. It brings too much embarrassment and not enough privacy.    But my colleague Catherine received most of her treatment...

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are wearier after their vacations than before them, a Gallup poll has found. The survey found that fewer than a third of Americans took breaks lasting longer than nine days.
docs.abstract: Gallup survey finds fewer than 33 percent of Americans take vacations lasting longer than nine days, about 33 percent of working adults put in more hours in office the week before vacation, 46 percent of those surveyed feel tired before vacation and 54 percent feel tired afterward; Penn State Prof Roger Cadieux offers suggestions; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Americans are wearier after their vacations than before them, a Gallup poll has found.    The survey found that fewer than a third of Americans took breaks lasting longer than nine days.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Bonnie Fass-Offit joined a pediatric practice in suburban Philadelphia 12 years ago, she tried to follow her conviction that children should not take antibiotics or over-the-counter medications unless they were necessary. She explained to parents that antibiotics did not cure viral infections and why she thought limiting over-the-counter drugs was a wise course for their sick children. Sometimes, though, a parent would get a child's prescription from another doctor.

headline.main: Use of Antibiotics in Children Is Down, but Enough?

docs.lead_paragraph: ''My Twice-Lived Life: A Memoir of Aging,'' by Donald M. Murray, Ballantine, $21.95. ''Learning to Fall: The Blessings of an Imperfect Life,'' by Philip Simmons, Bantam, $16.95. These reflective, eloquent books are about coping with what life deals us and seizing control of it, about living in the moment, and, ultimately, about accepting our lot.

headline.main: Learning and Accepting As the Days Grow Few

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews books My Twice-Lived Life: A Memoir of Aging by Donald M Murray and Learning to Fall: The Blessings of an Imperfect Life by Philip Simmons; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A number of misconceptions surround many of the most common childhood ailments and how or whether they should be treated with over-the-counter remedies. The following are common maladies and experts' recommendations for treating them. BACTERIAL INFECTIONS -- Distinguishing between viral and bacterial infections can be difficult, but the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have published guidelines to help doctors make the call.

headline.main: Fever Phobia, and Other Parental Bugaboos

docs.abstract: Article, seeking to clear up common misconceptions about common childhood ailments, describes maladies and recommended treatments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If you think you have trouble controlling your caloric intake when food seems to be everywhere you turn, think what it must be like for children born constantly hungry, unable to feel full or satisfied and, as a result, constantly obsessed with food and eating. Think, too, what it must be like for their parents, who must keep every edible locked away and severely restrict the daily diets of their children lest they balloon to 400 unhealthy pounds.

headline.main: Disorder Makes Hunger a Constant Companion

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column describes causes and treament of Prader-Willi syndrome, complex genetic disorder that can lead to obsessive eating disorder in children; drawing (M)
